prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The velocity range of the MW disk is 0-120km/s. The smallest structures that we propose to detect and potentially resolve have the velocity width of 0.2km/s (i.e., the sound speed of the gas at 10K). We want to have 3-4 channels within the 0.2km/s width. Therefore, we need the following correlator configurations for each science goal:
- CO J=1-0 observations
* One 58MHz band to detect and potentially resolve the 0.2km/s width. * One 117MHz band to detect any absorption slightly beyond the expected velocity range of the MW. * Two 1875MHz continuum bands for calibration (we will use selfcal as well as regular phase cal for sanity check).
- 13CO&C18O J=1-0 observations
* One 58MHz band for 13CO, to detect and potentially resolve the 0.2km/s width. * One 58MHz band for C18O, to detect and potentially resolve the 0.2km/s width. * Two 1875MHz continuum bands for calibration (we will use selfcal as well as regular phase cal for sanity check).
- CO,13CO,C18O J=2-1 observations
* One 117MHz band for CO, to detect and potentially resolve the 0.2km/s width. * One 117MHz band for 13CO, to detect and potentially resolve the 0.2km/s width. * One 117MHz band for C18O, to detect and potentially resolve the 0.2km/s width. * One 1875MHz continuum band for calibration (we will use selfcal as well as regular phase cal for sanity check).

This project does not need to image the data, but simply add the spectra of all baselines. The spatial resolution is set by the angular sizes of the two QSOs (<10 milli-arcsec) and does not constrain the array configuration.
However, we need to resolve-out extended foreground emission in the MW, and do not want to include **too much** short baselines (including some short baselines, say about 20-30%, is fine). The majority of the baselines should be longer than about 200m for Band 3 and about 100m for Band 6. A possible presence of emission line contamination will be checked by a jackknife approach - by splitting the spectra between short and long baselines and checking any difference.

This is an absorption study of very small molecular clumps in GMCs across the MW mid-plane using two QSOs behind the MW disk. We propose to achieve the RMS sensitivity of 8mJy in a 0.2km/s resolution. This sensitivity gives 5-sigma detections of the absorbed continuum flux of 40mJy (=f_cont*exp(-tau)) at tau=2.0 in 0.2km/s.
This sensitivity calculation is based on their flat continuum fluxes of f_cont=300mJy both in Band 3 and 6, which is a conservative estimation based on our CARMA observations.
The velocity range of the MW disk is 0-120km/s. The small clumps have the expected velocity width of 0.2km/s (i.e., the sound speed of the gas at 10K).

The data rate exceeds the maximum of 12.00MB/s. This is necessary for observing multiple lines simultaneously at the high velocity resolution and coverage, as well as obtaining continuum bands for calibration (we will use selfcal as well as regular phase cal for sanity check).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: By utilizing two QSOs directly behind the Mikly Way mid-plane, we propose the absorption study of the molecular ISM in the MW in CO, 13CO, and C18O J=1-0 and 2-1 transitions. The compact QSO sizes (<10 milliarcsec), combined with the high sensitivity of ALMA, will provide the highest spatial resolution (<100AU at 10kpc) and velocity resolution (0.2km/s; sound speed of the cold molecular gas). We will (1) detect the theoretically-predicted, yet unproven, smallest molecular structures within ~10 GMCs across the MW, (2) measure the gas column density, temperature, and CO-isotope ratios in the typical molecular ISM across the MW disk with precision, and (3) search for the diffuse, extremely cold CO gas possibly not excited for emission.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astronomy Program, New York at Stony Brook, State University of

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Physics Mathematics and Astronomy, California Institute of Technology
